sen.j: 本沢 竹雲（もとさわ ちくうん、1836年3月26日（天保7年2月10日_(旧暦)）- 1907年（明治40年）10月13日）は「チョンマゲ学校」として知られる山形県東村山郡所在の格知学舎を開いた浄土真宗の僧で漢学者。
sen.e: Born on March 26, 1836, and gone on October 13, 1907, Chikuun Motosawa was a priest of "Jodo Shinshu" (True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) and a Japanese scholar of the Chinese classics, who founded "Kakuchi gakusha" (Kakuchi school), known as "chonmage gakko" (the school of must-wear a Japanese topknot), located in the present Higashi Murayama-gun, Yamagata Prefecture.
sen.cmt: ・文末の「漢学」は「漢学者」の誤りと解されますので訂正して訳しています。
sen.e: Born on March 26, 1836, and died on October 13, 1907, Chikuun Motosawa was a priest of "Jodo Shinshu" (True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) and a Japanese scholar of the Chinese classics, who founded "Kakuchi gakusha" (the Kakuchi school), known as "chonmage gakko" (the school of must-wear a Japanese topknot), located in the present Higashi Murayama-gun, Yamagata Prefecture.

sen.j: 幼名は八郎、通称は俊丸（としまる）、本名は盛遜。
sen.e: His childhood name was "Hachiro," and his common name was "Toshimaru," and his real name was "Seison."

sen.j: 竹雲は雅号であるが、他に老山、虎山、虚堂、寄嘱子の号 (称号)があった。
sen.e: "Chikuun" was his pseudonym, and he also had other appellations, such as Rozan, Kozan, Kyodo and Kishokushi.

sen.j: 本沢竹雲は、天保7年2月10日（1836年3月26日）、長谷堂（山形市）の西養寺住職安達秀恩の末子として生まれた。
sen.e: Chikuun Motosawa was born as the youngest son of Shuon ADACHI, the chief priest of Saiyo-ji Temple in Hasedo (the present Yamagata City).

Chikuun MOTOSAWA was born the youngest son of Shuon ADACHI, the chief priest of Saiyo-ji Temple in Hasedo (the present Yamagata City) in March 26, 1836.
sen.cmt: 表記を指示書に合わせ、年月補足しました。

sen.j: 幼少より書道を好み、父からは漢籍を学んでこれに親しんだという。
sen.e: He is said to have loved calligraphy from his childhood, and to have spent a lot of time studying Chinese classics under his father.

sen.j: 弘化4年（1847年）、姉の嫁ぎ先である二位田村（山形市）の明円寺に寄寓する。
sen.e: In 1847, Chikuun temporarily lived in Meien-ji Temple (the home of his elder sister's husband family) located in Niita Village (part of today's Yamagata City).

sen.j: 翌嘉永元年、その隣村で陣屋のあった佐倉藩領の柏倉（山形市）の藩校千葉県立佐倉高等学校北庠に通った。
sen.e: In the next year of 1848, he went to the north branch of "Seitoku Shoin" (the present Chiba Prefectural Sakura Senior High School), which was "hanko" (domain school) located in Kashiwakura Village (Kashiwakura Village was then part of the Sakura domain, neighboring Niita Village, and managing "jinya" [regional government office]).

sen.j: 嘉永4年（1851年）には上山藩の藩校明新館で歴史や四書五経の勉学に努め、また、五十嵐龍渓を師として書道を学んでいる。
sen.e: In 1851, he studied history and "shishogokyo" (the Four Books and Five Classics of Confucianism) at Meishinkan (the Kaminoyama domain's hanko), and also learned calligraphy from Ryukei IGARASHI.

sen.j: 翌嘉永5年（1852年）には姉夫婦の養子として正式に入籍し、こののち本沢姓を名乗るようになった。
sen.e: In the next year of 1852, he formally had his name entered his elder sister's family register as an adoptee, and thereafter bore the family name of Motosawa.

sen.j: 同年、米沢藩の片山塾でも指導を仰いだが、実家の都合により中途退学し、明円寺に戻って僧侶となる修行に取り組んだ。
sen.e: In the same year, he went to "Katayama Juku" (the Yonezawa domain's hanko), but quit for some reason of his parents' home, and then he returned to Meien-ji Temple and implemented ascetic practices to become a priest.

sen.j: しかし、向学心の衰えない竹雲は安政4年（1857年）、京都へおもむき浄土真宗の高倉学寮に入学して漢詩や漢文学を勉強した。
sen.e: However, Chikuun kept his passion for knowledge, and so, in 1857, he went to Kyoto and entered "Takakura Gakuryo" (the seminary of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple of Jodo Shinshu, today's Otani University), where he studied Chinese poetry and Chinese classics.

sen.j: 翌安政5年（1858年）には江戸の藤森弘庵に師事して、経論と文学を学んだのち帰郷した。
sen.e: In the next year of 1858, he studied statecraft and literature under Koan FUJIMORI in Edo, and then went back to his home town.

sen.j: そののち再度江戸におもむいた竹雲は安井息軒の三計塾を継ぐよう求められたがそれを断った。
sen.e: When Chikuun visited Edo again afterward, he was asked to succeed "Sankei Juku," which was a private school founded by Sokken YASUI, but he declined.

sen.j: また、幕政の立て直しのために見識を求められて江戸幕府の議に参画したこともあったが、そこからも離れた。

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年）には再び郷里に戻り、上山市の明新館の督学となって後進の指導にあたった。
sen.e: In 1867, he returned to his home town again, became "tokugaku" (a school inspector) of Meishinkan in Kaminoyama City, and taught the younger generation.

sen.j: しかし明治2年（1869年）2月、門下生であった貫津（ぬくつ）村（天童市）名主結城六右衛門の招きで五老山の麓に塾舎「格知学舎」を開設することとなった。
sen.e: But in February 1869, he decided to open his school named Kakuchi gakusha at the foot of Mt. Goro on the recommendation of his pupil Rokuemon YUKI, who was "nanushi" (village headman) of Nukutsu Village (part of the present Tendo City).

sen.e: "Rozan," which is one of Chikuun's appellations, comes from this Mt. Goro (in Japanese, reads as "Gorozan"), by which the school was located.

sen.j: それ以来三十年余の長きにわたって、格知学舎で仏教、儒教を中心に漢学の指導に当たった。
sen.e: Thereafter, he taught Chinese classics - mainly, Buddhism and Confucianism - at Kakuchi gakusha as long as 30-odd years.

sen.j: 門弟に対しては「学問は心と身を善に移す外無之候」という自筆の書付を手渡し、学問とは人の道を歩み実践するためのものであることを説いた。
sen.e: He tried to instill in his pupils that the pupose of study is to practice moral principles, by, for example, giving his hand-written memo that says, "The purpose of study is nothing but to make one's spirit and deeds good."

sen.j: また熱心な佐幕論者であった竹雲は、世間が欧化主義へと向かい、万事洋風化して、日本古来の文化や伝統が失われていくことを嘆いていた。
sen.e: Chikuun was an earnest supporter of the Tokugawa shogunate, so he deplored the loss of ancient Japanese culture and tradition in the public trend toward the adovocacy of Europeanization and the all-European-style life.

sen.j: それゆえ格知寮で近郷地主層の子弟と起居をともにしながら、自ら丁髷を結い和服を着た生活を送ったため、「チョンマゲ先生」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Therefore, he himself wore a Japanese topknot and Japanese clothes, living together at the dormitory of Kakuchi gakusha with sons who came from land-owning classes in the neighboring villages.

sen.j: 門弟にも和装とマゲの生活を求め、マゲを結うことが門人たる資格条件とされた。

sen.j: 竹雲の舶来品嫌いは徹底しており、蒸気機関車にも乗らず、ランプ (照明器具)も用いなかった。
sen.e: Chikuun hated the European culture to the bone, so he did not get on a steam locomotive, nor did he use a gas lamp.

sen.e: Chikuun's knowledge was so profound that he was admired as "Three Great Confucianists around Murayama" along with Ton SUGAWARA in Yuzawa (the present Murayama City) and Shion SAGAE in Nagatoro (the present Higashine City).
